description: From Anglo-Norman runger, ultimately of imitative origin.

verbs.description: roin (third-person singular simple present roins, present participle roining, simple past and past participle roined)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, intransitive) To growl; to roar. [15th–17th c.]

description: From Anglo-Norman roigne, roin et al., of uncertain origin. Compare roynish.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A scab; a scurf, or scurfy spot. [15th–16th c.]
